intro: Vaccinium atrococcum, commonly known as the black huckleberry, is a shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes other familiar plants like blueberries and azaleas. The plant produces small, dark purple to black berries that are typically consumed by wildlife such as birds and bears. Its leaves are elliptical, dark green, and have a leathery texture, while its flowers are bell-shaped and pinkish-white. Vaccinium atrococcum thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded environments like forests and streamside areas.
